00001 /*
00002 Title:    Atmel Microcontroller Not a Real Time Operating System (NARTOS)
00003 Author:   Ken Sarkies ksarkies at trinity.asn.au
00004 File:     $Id: nartos.h, v 0.1 6/6/2007 $
00005 Software: AVR-GCC 3.4.5
00006 Target:   ATMega AVR with UART, TWI and ADC functions
00007 Tested:   ATMega48 at 8MHz, using UART, TWI.
00008 
00009 DESCRIPTION:
00010 Starts a task by placing its address into a task table and an index (task
00011 ID)into the table onto a scheduling queue. The OS pulls the next index from the
00012 queue and accesses the task address for execution. Tasks can relinquish by
00013 putting their next execution address into their slot in the table and their ID
00014 onto the queue. They can wait indefinitely until another task or an ISR
00015 reschedules them.
00016 
00017 No context apart from the execution address is saved. Programmers must ensure
00018 that no context must be preserved across a call to relinquish or wait. This
00019 means that these calls must be made in a top level scope, and variables to be
00020 preserved are made global volatile.
00021 
00022 taskStart will create a new task and give a taskID back.
00023 One task at least must be started in the main program, which then jumps into
00024 the nartos to execute the tasks on the queue.
00025 
00026 A task must run for a while and then call taskRelinquish or taskWait to give
00027 other tasks a go (usually in a loop waiting for something to happen).
00028 
00029 taskWait suspends the task indefinitely until an ISR or another task
00030 reschedules it with taskSchedule.
00031 
00032 taskExit must be called when the task has completed.
00033 
00034 The main program needs to initialise nartos and call a first task before
00035 exiting to the OS:
00036 
00037 int main(void)
00038 {
00039   initNartos();
00040   firstTaskID = taskStart((uint16_t)*firstTask,FALSE);
00041   nartos();
00042 }
00043 */
00044

00067 /* This defines the maximum number of tasks */
00068 #define queueLength 8
00069 /* This allows the use of a two-level priority, but takes more program space. */
00070 //#define PRIORITY_QUEUE
00071 
00072 /* Functions declared "naked" stop any saving of context and remove the
00073 return instruction. They are not really functions as such. */
00074 
00075 /*-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00076 Relinquish control of the processor temporarily.
00077 This drops out to the OS with the task ID placed on the queue
00078 The return address is recovered from the stack and put into the task table
00079 Never to be called from an ISR. */
00080 
00081 void taskRelinquish(void) __attribute__ ((naked));
00082 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00083 Terminate the calling task
00084 Pop stack to remove and discard the return address put there by the call.
00085 Remove the task entry from the task table.
00086 Never to be called from an ISR. */
00087 
00088 void taskExit(void)       __attribute__ ((naked));
00089 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00090 Enter an indefinite waiting state. It is up to another task or ISR to
00091 reschedule the task.
00092 The return address is recovered from the stack and put into the task table
00093 Never to be called from an ISR. */
00094 
00095 void taskWait(void)       __attribute__ ((naked));
00096 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00097 This is the main OS loop. Should not be called directly except at the end of
00098 the main program.
00099 Pop the stack to remove any return address put there by the call.
00100 Wait if there are no tasks present. Assume that an ISR will start a task
00101 sometime.
00102 Get the next task off the queue and jump to its stored address by pushing
00103 it onto the stack and executing a reti (which enables interrupts at the
00104 same time).
00105 taskBufferOutPointer indicates the next location with a taskID to be run,
00106 except in the case where the queue is empty (taskBufferSize = 0).
00107 
00108 In the high priority case, taskBufferOutPointer points to a location beyond
00109 the first high priority entry to be accessed, therefore it is decremented
00110 first. If it is zero then it must first be set to point to the top buffer
00111 location. The taskBufferPrioritySize is decremented and the taskBufferSize
00112 must be decremented also as it holds the total length of the queue. */
00113 
00114 void nartos(void)         __attribute__ ((naked));
00115 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00116 Initialize the OS by clearing the task table and queue pointers. */
00117 
00118 void initNartos(void);
00119 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00120 Start a new task.
00121 This puts the function address pointer in the task table in a blank spot,
00122 and allocates the task ID. Places the task ID on the queue.
00123 Input:   address pointer to the start of the task
00124          boolean indicating if calling from an ISR
00125 Output:  task ID, 0 - queueLength if valid, =0xFF if no space left. */
00126 
00127 uint8_t taskStart(const uint16_t, const uint8_t);
00128 /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00129 Schedule a waiting task
00130 The taskID is placed on the queue.
00131 If the wrong taskID is used, the desired task will not be started and the
00132 OS will probably end up scheduling a second version of the task.
00133 If not called from an ISR, interrupts are enabled.
00134 Input:   the current task ID. Don't get it wrong!
00135          boolean indicating if calling from an ISR
00136 taskBufferOutPointer+taskBufferSize points to a location onto which a new
00137 taskID can be placed.
00138 Schedule a task with high priority by setting bit 7 of the taskID. */
00139 
00140 void taskSchedule(const uint8_t, const uint8_t);
00141
